Statistics.question:
Fixing $p\in(0, 1)$, let $c\_p=(2-p)/(1-p)$. (a). Show that if non-negative random variables \( V \) and \( A \) are such that
\[ \mathbb{P}(V \geq u) \leq \mathbb{P}(A \geq u) + \mathbb{E}[\min(A/u, 1)] \] for any \( u > 0 \), then \( \mathbb{E}[V^p] \leq c_p \mathbb{E}[A^p] \).

(b). Let \( A_n \) be the \( \mathcal{F}_n\)-predictable, non-decreasing sequence in Doob’s decomposition of a non-negative sub-martingale \( (X_n, \mathcal{F}_n) \) that starts at \( X_0  = 0 \) (that is, \( A_0 = 0 \) and \( Y_n = X_n - A_n \text{ is an } \mathcal{F}_n\)-martingale). Show that \( \mathbb{P}(V_\tau \geq u) \leq u^{-1}\mathbb{E}(A_\tau) \) for \( V_n = \max(X_0, X_1, \ldots, X_n) \), any finite \( \mathcal{F}_n\)-stopping time \( \tau \) and all \( u > 0 \).

(c). Conclude that in this case \( \mathbb{E}[V_\tau^2] \leq c_p\mathbb{E}[A_\tau^2] \).
reference_answer:
\begin{enumerate}[label=(\alph*)]
\item  Since \(V\) and \(A\) are non-negative random variables, using \textit{Integration by parts} formula and \textit{Fubini's Theorem} we get the following. Note that while evaluating the integrals in \((i)\) we have used \(p \in (0,1)\).
\begin{align*}
\mathbb{E}\left[ V^p\right] = \int_{0}^{\infty} pu^{p-1}\mathbb{P}(V \geq u) \, du & \leq \int_{0}^{\infty} pu^{p-1}\mathbb{P}(A \geq u) \, du + \int_{0}^{\infty} pu^{p-1}\mathbb{E} \left( \min(A/u,1)\right) \, du \\
&= \mathbb{E}\left[ A^p\right] +  \mathbb{E} \left[\int_{0}^{\infty} pu^{p-1} \min(A/u,1) \,du \right] \\
& = \mathbb{E}\left[ A^p\right] +  \mathbb{E} \left[ \int_{0}^{A} pu^{p-1} \,du  + \int_{A}^{\infty} pu^{p-1} Au^{-1}\,du\right] \\
& \stackrel{(i)}{=} \mathbb{E}\left[ A^p\right] +  \mathbb{E} \left[A^p  + \dfrac{pA^p}{1-p}\right] = \dfrac{2-p}{1-p} \mathbb{E}\left[ A^p\right] = c_p \mathbb{E}\left[ A^p\right].
\end{align*}

\item We have non-negative sub-MG \(\left\{X_n, \mathcal{F}_n,n \geq 0\right\}\) with \(X_0=0\) and corresponding increasing predictable process \(\left\{A_n\right\}_{n \geq 0}\) with \(A_0=0\), i.e. \(\left\{Y_n=X_n-A_n, \mathcal{F}_n\right\}_{n \geq 0}\) is a MG. By definition, \(V_n := \max(X_0, \ldots, X_n)\). Therefore \(\left\{ X_{\tau \wedge n}, \mathcal{F}_n, n \geq 0\right\}\) is also a non-negative sub-MG and \(\left\{ Y_{\tau \wedge n}, \mathcal{F}_n, n \geq 0\right\}\) is MG. This gives \(\mathbb{E}X_{\tau \wedge n} = \mathbb{E}A_{\tau \wedge n} + \mathbb{E}Y_{\tau \wedge n} = \mathbb{E}A_{\tau \wedge n} + \mathbb{E}Y_0 = \mathbb{E}A_{\tau \wedge n}.


By \textit{Doob's Inequality} we have for \(u >0\),
\begin{equation}{\label{ineq}}
\mathbb{P}\left[V_{\tau \wedge n} \geq u \right] = \mathbb{P}\left[\max_{k=0}^{\tau \wedge n} X_{k} \geq u \right] = \mathbb{P}\left[\max_{k=0}^n X_{\tau \wedge k} \geq u \right]  \leq u^{-1} \mathbb{E}\left[X_{\tau \wedge n} \right] = u^{-1} \mathbb{E}\left[A_{\tau \wedge n} \right].
\end{equation}

Since \(\tau\) is finite almost surely, by \textit{Monotone Convergence Theorem}, as \(n \to \infty\), \(\mathbb{E}A_{\tau \wedge n} \uparrow \mathbb{E}A_{\tau}.*\) Similarly,
$$ (V_{\tau \wedge n} \geq u) =\left( \max_{k=0}^{\tau \wedge n} X_{k} \geq u \right) = \left( \max_{k=0}^n X_{\tau \wedge k} \geq u \right) \uparrow  \left( \sup_{k=0}^{\infty} X_{\tau \wedge k} \geq u \right) = \left( \sup_{k=0}^{\tau} X_{k} \geq u \right) = (V_{\tau} \geq u).$$
Hence, taking \(n \to \infty\) in (\ref{ineq}) we get \(\mathbb{P}\left[V_{\tau} \geq u \right] \leq u^{-1}\mathbb{E}A_{\tau}.

*\item Consider the \(\mathcal{F}\)-stopping time \(\theta := \left\{ n \geq 0 : A_{n+1}>u\right\}\. Since, \(\left\{A_n\right\}_{n \geq 0}\) is predictable, this is a \(\mathcal{F}\)-stopping time. Note that,
$$ \mathbb{P}(V_{\tau} \geq u, \theta \geq \tau) \leq \mathbb{P}(V_{\tau \wedge \theta} \geq u) \leq u^{-1}\mathbb{E}A_{\tau \wedge \theta} \leq u^{-1} \mathbb{E} \left[A_{\tau} \wedge u \right],$$
where the first inequality is true since the process \(V\) is non-decreasing, the second inequality follows from the arguments similar to the one presented in (b), since \(\tau \wedge \theta\) is almost surely finite \(\mathcal{F}\)-stopping time and the third inequality follows from the fact that the process \(A\) is non-decreasing with \(A_{\theta} \leq u\. Therefore,
\begin{align*}
\mathbb{P} \left[V_{\tau} \geq u \right]  = \mathbb{P} \left[V_{\tau} \geq u , \theta \geq \tau\right]  + \mathbb{P} \left[V_{\tau} \geq u, \theta < \tau \right] &\leq u^{-1} \mathbb{E} \left[A_{\tau} \wedge u \right] + \mathbb{P} \left[\theta < \tau \right]\\
& =  \mathbb{E} \left[(A_{\tau}/u) \wedge 1 \right] + \mathbb{P}(A_{\tau} > u).
\end{align*}
Now we use part (a) to conclude that \(\mathbb{E}\left[ V_{\tau}^p\right] \leq c_p\mathbb{E}\left[ A_{\tau}^p\right].

Statistics.subject: Statistics
Statistics.question:
Recall that the Ornstein-Uhlenbeck process \( U_t = e^{-t/2} W_{e^t}, t \geq 0 \), derived from a standard Brownian motion \(\{ W_t, t \geq 0 \} \) (with \( W_0 = 0 \), is a homogeneous, zero-mean, Gaussian Markov process, such that \( \mathbb{E}(U_t | U_0) = e^{-t/2}U_0 \) and \( \text{Var}(U_t | U_0) = 1 - e^{-t} \).

(a). What is the transition probability kernel \( p_t(x, y) \) for the Markov semi-group of this process?

(b). Find the law of \( U_t \) and explain why \( (U_t, t \geq 0) \) is a stationary process.

(c). Suppose \( (X,Y) \) is a zero mean Gaussian random vector such that \( \mathbb{E}X^2 = \mathbb{E}Y^2 = 1 \) and \( \mathbb{E}[XY] = c \geq 0 \). Fixing a non-empty interval \( I = [a, b) \) of the real line, is the function \( g(c) = \mathbb{P}( X \in I,  Y \in I ) \) nondecreasing in \( c \)? Prove or give a counter-example.

Hint: For the Hilbert space \( \mathcal{H} \) of norm \( ||h|| = (h,h)^{1/2} \) and inner product \( (h,f) = \frac{1}{\sqrt{2 \pi}} \int h(x)f(x)e^{-x^2/2}dx \), it is known that for any \( t > 0 \) and \( f \in \mathcal{H} \),
\[ (p_tf)(x) := \int p_t(x,y)f(y)dy = \kappa \sum_{n = 0}^{\infty} e^{- ancynot{a}_n t}(\psi_n, f)\psi_n(x), \] with \( \kappa > 0 \) a finite constant, \( 0 < \fancynot{a}_0 < \fancynot{a}_1 < \ldots \) and functions \( \psi_n(.) \) such that \( ||\psi_n|| = 1 \), and where the series on the right-side converges weakly in \( S \) to \( p_tf \).
reference_answer:
\begin{enumerate}[label=(\alph*)]
\item The O-U process is homogeneous Gaussian Markov process with \(\mathbb{E}(U_t|U_0) =\exp(-t/2)U_0\) and \(\operatorname{Var}(U_t|U_0) = 1-\exp(-t)\). Therefore, the transition probability kernel is as follows.
\begin{align*}
 p_t(x,y) &= \text{Density of } N\left( \exp(-t/2)x,1-\exp(-t)\right) \text{ distribution at } y \\
 &= (1-e^{-t})^{-1/2} \phi \left( (1-e^{-t})^{-1/2}(y-xe^{-t/2}) \right) \\
 &= \dfrac{1}{\sqrt{2 \pi (1-e^{-t})}} \exp \left( - \dfrac{(y-xe^{-t/2})^2}{2(1-e^{-t})}\right).
 \end{align*}  
 
 \item \(U_t = \exp(-t/2)W_{e^t}\) and \(W_s \sim N(0,s)\) for all \(s \geq 0\). Hence, \(U_t \sim N(0,1).\)
 \n Note that for any \(s,t \geq 0\), we have 
 $$\operatorname{Cov}(U_t,U_s) = \exp(-t/2-s/2)\operatorname{Cov}(W_{e^t},W_{e^s}) = \exp(-t/2-s/2)(e^t \wedge e^s) = \exp(-|t-s|/2). $$ 
Thus the O-U Process is weakly stationary and being a Gaussian process it implies that it is (strongly) stationary.
 \item Set \(t = -2\log c\). Then for \(c \in (0,1)\), we clearly have from the covariance expression of part (b) that \((X,Y) \stackrel{d}{=} (U_0,U_t)\). Set \(f := \mathbbm{1}_{[a,b)}\). Clearly, 
 \(\int_{\mathbb{R}} f^2(x) \phi(x) \, dx < \infty\) and hence \(f \in \mathbb{H}\. 
 \begin{align*}
 g(c)=\mathbb{P}(X \in I, Y \in I) =  \mathbb{P}(U_0 \in I, U_t \in I) = \mathbb{E}\left[f(U_0)f(U_t) \right] &= \int_{\mathbb{R}} \mathbb{E}\left[f(U_t) |U_0=x\right] f(x) \phi(x) \, dx \\
 &= \int_{\mathbb{R}} \left[\int_{\mathbb{R}}f(y)p_t(x,y)\,dy \right] f(x) \phi(x) \, dx \\
 &= \int_{\mathbb{R}} p_tf(x) f(x) \phi(x) \, dx = (p_tf,f). 
 \end{align*}  
Set
$$ h_n := \kappa \sum_{k=0}^n \exp(-\lambda_kt)(\psi_k,f)\psi_k.$$ 
We know that \(h_n\) converges weakly to \(p_tf\) and therefore \((h_n,f) \longrightarrow (p_tf,f)\). On the otherhand,
$$ (h_n,f) =  \kappa \left(\sum_{k=0}^n \exp(-\lambda_kt)(\psi_k,f)\psi_k,f \right) = \kappa \sum_{k=0}^n \exp(-\lambda_kt)(\psi_k,f)(\psi_k,f) = \kappa \sum_{k=0}^n \exp(-\lambda_kt)|(\\psi_k,f)|^2 ,$$
and hence,
$$ g(c)=\mathbb{P}(X \in I, Y \in I) = (p_tf,f) =  \kappa \sum_{k=0}^{\infty} \exp(-\lambda_kt)|(\\psi_k,f)|^2$$
Since, \(\kappa>0\) and \(\lambda_k \geq 0\) for all \(k \geq 0\), we have the right hand side and hence \(g\) to be non-decreasing on \((0,1)\). The function \(g\) is continuous on \([0,1]\) as can be seen from its integral expression. Therefore, \(g\) is non-decreasing on \([0,1]\.  
\end{enumerate}

A function \( L : (0, \infty) \rightarrow \mathbb{R} \) is said to be slowly varying (at \( \infty \)) if
\[ \lim_{x \to \infty} \frac{L(cx)}{L(x)} = 1 \text{ for all } c > 0. \]

(a). Suppose martingale \( (M_t,\mathcal{F}_t) \) starting at \( M_0 = 0 \), is such that \( \max_{k \leq n} |M_k - M_{k-1}| \leq a_n \) and for any \( 0 < \epsilon \leq 1 \), as \( n \to \infty \),
\[ \frac{1}{nL(a_n)} \sum_{k=1}^{n} \mathbb{E} \left( (M_k - M_{k-1})^2 \mathbf{1}(|M_k - M_{k-1}| \leq \epsilon a_n)| \mathcal{F}_{k-1} \right) \xrightarrow{P} 1 \]evergs in distribution on \( C([0, 1]) \) to the standard Brownian motion.

Statistics.question: Suppose $Z_n$ is a non-decreasing sequence of finite valued, non-negative random variables such that $Z_n \to \infty$ almost surely. Show that then $ \lim \sup_n (\log Z_n / (\log \mathbb{E}Z_n)) \leq 1$ almost surely.
reference_answer:
We have non-negative increasing sequence of almost surely finite random variables $\left\{Z_n \right\}_{n \geq 1}$ such that $Z_n \uparrow \infty$ almost surely. We need to show 
$$ \limsup_{n \to \infty} \dfrac{\log Z_n}{\log \mathbb{E}Z_n} \leq 1, \; \text{almost surely}.$$\nWithout loss of generality we can assume that $a_n := \mathbb{E}Z_n$ is finite for all $n \geq 1$, because otherwise $a_n =\infty$ for all $n \geq N$, for some $N \in \mathbb{N}$ and therefore the concerned limsup will be $0$ almost surely.
\nSince $Z_n \uparrow \infty$ almost surely, by MCT we have $a_n \uparrow \infty$. Hence we can construct the subsequence $\left\{n_k \right\}_{k \geq 0}$ as follows. $n_0:=1$ and 
$$ n_{l+1} := \inf \left\{j \geq n_l+1 : a_j > 2^{l+1} \right\}, \;\forall \; l \geq 0.$$\nFor any $\delta >0$,
\begin{align*}
\sum_{l \geq 1} \mathbb{P} \left[ \dfrac{\log Z_{n_{l+1}-1}}{\log \mathbb{E}Z_{n_l}} \geq 1+ \delta \right] = \sum_{l \geq 1} \mathbb{P} \left[ Z_{n_{l+1}-1} \geq a_{n_l}^{1+\delta} \right]  \leq \sum_{l \geq 1} \dfrac{a_{n_{l+1}-1}}{a_{n_l}^{1+\delta}} \stackrel{(i)}{\leq} \sum_{l \geq 1} 2^{1-l\delta} < \infty,
\end{align*}
where $(i)$ holds true since either $n_{l+1}=n_l+1$ in which case the corresponding summand is at most $a_{n_l}^{-\delta} \leq 2^{-l\delta}$ or $n_{l+1}>n_l+1$ in which case $a_{n_{l+1}-1} \leq 2^{l+1}$ and hence the summand is at most $2^{l+1}2^{-l(1+\delta)}$.
Hence, by \textit{Borel-Cantelli Lemma}, we have 
$$  \mathbb{P} \left[ \dfrac{\log Z_{n_{l+1}-1}}{\log \mathbb{E}Z_{n_l}} \geq 1+ \delta  \textit{ infinitely often }\right] = 0 \Rightarrow   \limsup_{l \to \infty} \dfrac{\log Z_{n_{l+1}-1}}{\log \mathbb{E}Z_{n_{l}}} \leq 1+\delta, \; \text{almost surely}.$$\nSince, this holds true for all $\delta >0$, we have\n\begin{equation} {\label{conv}}\n\limsup_{l \to \infty} \dfrac{\log Z_{n_{l+1}-1}}{\log \mathbb{E}Z_{n_{l}}} \leq 1, \; \text{almost surely}.
\end{equation}\n\nFor all $k \geq 1$, let $m(k) := \sup \left\{l \geq 0 : n_l \leq k \right\}$. Observe that $m(k) \longrightarrow \infty$ as $k \longrightarrow \infty$ and $n_{m(k)+1}-1 \geq k \geq n_{m(k)}$. Using the monotonicity of the sequence $\left\{Z_n\right\}_{n \geq 1}$ and $\left\{a\right\}_{n \geq 1}$ we get
$$  \limsup_{k \to \infty} \dfrac{\log Z_k}{\log \mathbb{E}Z_k}  \leq 
\limsup_{k \to \infty} \dfrac{\log Z_{n_{m(k)+1}-1}}{\log \mathbb{E}Z_{n_{m(k)}}} \leq 1, \; \text{almost surely},$$\nwhere the last assertion follows from (\ref{conv}). This completes the proof.

$$ || 	ext{Poisson}(\lambda_n) - 	ext{Poisson}(\lambda)||_{TV} = \dfrac{1}{2}\sum_{j \in \mathbb{Z}} |\mathbb{P}(	ext{Poisson}(\lambda_n)=j) - \mathbb{P}(	ext{Poisson}(\lambda)=j)| =o(1).$$
	extit{Triangle inequality} for 	extit{Total Variation Distance} now implies that $|| \mathcal{L}(E_n) -  	ext{Poisson}(\lambda)||_{TV} =o(1)$, which implies $E_n \stackrel{d}{\longrightarrow} 	ext{Poisson}(\lambda).$
\end{enumerate}

Economics/Business.subject: Economics (Public Economics, Government Intervention, Welfare Policy)
Economics/Business.question: Based on Passage A, analyze the advantages and disadvantages of whether the government's responsibility and role performance applies positively or negatively to the national economy, and discuss your views using Passages B, C, D, E, and F.
reference_answer:
Passage A emphasizes the positive aspects where the government secures legitimacy for intervention in the market economy with the purpose of protecting national interests. Based on this role of government, we can derive the result that Passage B and D show the negative aspects of government market intervention, Passage C and F show the positive aspects of the government's role, and Passage E shows that both sides exist.

Passage B shows that the deterioration of management performance of public enterprises and the increase in debt has a negative impact on citizens and the national economy by placing a financial burden, as the operation of public enterprises is covered by taxes. Therefore, Passage B shows that the government's market intervention through public enterprises has a negative impact on economic development.

In Passage C, while the state performs the responsibility and role of protecting citizens through social insurance, national health insurance, national pension, etc. are risk factors that can worsen the state's financial burden and have potential elements that can have a negative impact from an economic perspective.

Passage D, based on historical facts, shows that when the government intervenes in the market economy, stagflation arises, which is also connected to the neoliberal argument that government intervention should be reduced. In particular, it indicates that government intervention in the market does not help solve problems in crisis situations such as oil shocks.

Passage E emphasizes that the UK's Brexit decision can have both positive and negative impacts on the economy simultaneously.

Passage F emphasizes the welfare responsibilities and roles for citizens, such as medical expenses and livelihood support in case of unemployment. However, it has a connection that more effort should be put into economic development to maintain the social security system.

Government intervention in the market for economic development and welfare has both positive and negative aspects, as in Passage E. However, inefficiency can be mentioned as in Passage B and D, or positive aspects linked to welfare can be presented as in Passage C and F.
comment:
This question requires an understanding of the government's role in overall economic activities, including economic growth, businesses, job creation, etc., which are covered in the high school <Economics> subject. It evaluates whether students can classify the passages according to perspectives that support or deny the validity of the government's economic activities to fulfill its roles and responsibilities related to economic growth, especially in terms of social infrastructure, welfare for citizens, retirement, etc.

Students analyze the advantages and disadvantages through the passages, recognizing what responsibilities the government has toward stakeholders such as individuals and businesses who lead economic activities, and what results these activities bring. In particular, the passages aim to analyze the advantages and disadvantages of the government's active intervention in economic activities and citizen welfare, and to derive results. Based on these passages, students distinguish whether the nation's responsibility and role performance acts positively or negatively in economic terms, and derive advantages and disadvantages.

The process of solving this question is as follows:

First, read Passage A to understand the concept of state intervention in the economy. Use Passage A as a standard to identify the advantages and disadvantages of state intervention in the passages below.

Second, identify the justification for why the government should privatize to solve public enterprise debt in Passage B. Determine whether the disadvantage of high debt ratios when the government intervenes in the market economy through public enterprises and bearing it with taxes is beneficial or harmful to citizens and the economy.

Third, read Passage C to understand the operation of the social insurance system, which is a state obligation, and analyze the issues of the state giving both benefits and burdens to the national economy and citizens for the operation of the social insurance system, the responsibility and role of the state, and the economic burden of operating the social insurance system.

Fourth, read Passage D, which talks about the responsibilities the state should have for a fair economy and public goods. Analyze economic activities while taking responsibility for fair economic intervention and public goods, and identify economic burdens and economic roles.

Fifth, read the Brexit case in Passage E to understand how a nation's decisions affect not only the domestic economy but also the world economy, and identify economic influences.

Finally, read Passage F, which emphasizes the economic role for maintaining the basic standard of living for citizens that the state should pursue.

Passage A explains the state's responsibility in its role in the market economy. It discusses the main role of government in its legitimacy in the market economy and protecting market participants. By presenting the roles that the government performs across the economy, including the national economic market, it shows the positive aspects of government market intervention.

Passage B shows that as the debt ratio of public enterprises increases and performance deteriorates, the government's economic activities are actually becoming a tax burden. It argues for the privatization of public enterprises to solve this problem. It claims that state intervention in the national economy through public enterprises is actually increasing the burden on citizens. It emphasizes that public enterprises are playing a negative role in economic activities.

Passage C emphasizes that the government plays a role in improving citizens' safe lives and quality of life through the social insurance system. The government, through financial support and cost-sharing, shares responsibility with various stakeholders including citizens who are subscribers to health insurance, national pension, employment insurance, industrial accident compensation insurance, and long-term care insurance for the elderly. While fulfilling its responsibilities and roles, it affects economic activities and has a negative impact in purely economic terms.

Passage D explains various side effects that can arise through excessive government intervention in the market economy. Particularly from a historical perspective, it explains the causes of the oil shock in the 70s and the related stagflation in the 80s in connection with government market intervention.

Passage E, using the example of Brexit in the UK, emphasizes how government and public decision-making affects not only the domestic economy but also the international economy. In the case of Brexit, it includes both positive and negative aspects in terms of economic activities. Therefore, it argues that the government's economic activity decisions do not influence in just one direction, either positive or negative.

Passage F talks about the roles and responsibilities that the state can have for its citizens. Like Passage C, it emphasizes the link between national economic activities and welfare through various social security systems to maintain citizens' welfare and guarantee the livelihood of the unemployed, and argues for the positive aspect that economic growth leads to the expansion of welfare systems.

Economics/Business.subject: Economics and Social Studies
Economics/Business.question: This question aims to identify the causes of the socially controversial chicken price increase through the changes in supply contained in the 'Economics' textbook of high school, and to address people's responses from the perspective of correct consumer behavior contained in the 'Integrated Social Studies' textbook of high school. Additionally, through the given passages, it helps understand that social consensus can be derived differently depending on which logic, political or economic, is applied, and that different aspects can emerge from a dialectical perspective depending on the point in time. This question evaluates whether one can organically connect concepts explained in multiple passages and explain them through logical procedures.
reference_answer:
Passage [A] explains factors that cause shifts in the supply curve, i.e., changes in supply. Passage [E] identifies increased delivery costs as the main reason for the rising price of chicken, which corresponds to an increase in the price of production inputs mentioned in Passage [A]. Thus, the rise in chicken prices can be connected to a shift in the supply curve resulting from increased production costs.
Passage [B] describes desirable consumer behaviors such as rational consumption, avoiding excessive overconsumption, and establishing consumer sovereignty. The chicken boycott introduced in Passage [F] exemplifies consumers clearly expressing their strong stance against price increases in the franchise chicken industry. By choosing to purchase non-franchise chicken, consumers practice rational consumption and assert their consumer sovereignty.
Passage [C] explains that political logic and economic logic can differ when dealing with the same issue. The incident of 'Tongkeun Chicken,' mentioned in Passage [F], whose sales were stopped just a week after its launch a decade ago, appears to have been influenced by political logic. However, given that similar products to 'Tongkeun Chicken' are now reintroduced without significant opposition from franchise chicken businesses, it indicates that the industry is hesitant to use political logic under current circumstances, where rising chicken prices have provoked consumer backlash. Furthermore, Passage [D] explains through dialectical logic that existing principles can be readjusted when faced with new circumstances. In the past, 'Tongkeun Chicken' was rejected by the public because it relied on economic logic based on unrealized benefits. However, as there is now tangible evidence of its positive effects, similar products have the potential to overcome past controversies and continue being sold.
comment: Passage [A] explains the factors that cause the shift of the supply curve, that is, changes in supply. [E] points to the increase in delivery costs as the main cause of chicken price increases, which corresponds to the increase in production factor prices in [A]. In other words, the rise in chicken prices can be linked to the shift of the supply curve due to the increase in production factor prices. Passage [B] explains that practicing rational consumption, avoiding indiscriminate overconsumption, establishing consumer sovereignty, etc., are desirable behaviors that consumers should maintain. The chicken boycott introduced in [F] is an example of consumers strongly expressing their intentions in response to price increases in the franchise chicken industry, and it is judged that consumers are realizing rational consumption and consumer sovereignty by purchasing non-franchise chicken. Passage [C] explains that political logic and economic logic can differ on the same issue. The incident where 'Tongkeun Chicken' was discontinued after just one week about 10 years ago, mentioned in [F], appears to be the result of political logic. However, at the present time when similar products to 'Tongkeun Chicken' are being re-released, the chicken franchise industry is unable to properly express opposition. This shows that the industry is not hastily approaching with political logic in a situation where it is facing consumer backlash due to rising chicken prices. Furthermore, [D] explains with dialectical logic that existing principles can be readjusted when faced with new situations. In the past, 'Tongkeun Chicken' was not accepted by the public because it presented economic logic based on unrealized profits, but now it suggests that similar products to 'Tongkeun Chicken' may continue to be sold despite controversy because a kind of result remains.

Economics/Business.subject: Economics (Information Asymmetry, Market Regulation, and Government Intervention)
Economics/Business.question: Using Passage A, explain Passages B and C, and using Passages D and E, discuss about Passages F and G.
reference_answer:
Passage A explains the information asymmetry. According to this concept, people may have different information from each other, and this can cause damage to economic agents. Specifically, a person who has a lot of information can harm a person who has little information by not sharing it.

Passage B shows an example of damage caused by information asymmetry in which homebuyers with relatively little information were victimized by fraud. In addition, Passage C states that individual investors in the bio-industry may be vulnerable to information asymmetry due to the characteristics of the industry, and they can often see damage from this.

Passage B and Passage C show various examples of damage to economic entities caused by information asymmetry in different fields.

The government sometimes intervenes to solve the damage caused by this information asymmetry. As shown in Passage F, the government tried to solve the damage to consumers caused by information asymmetry by passing a bill that mandates game companies to disclose information. In addition, Passage G shows that the government tried to introduce a system that requires executives and major shareholders of listed companies to disclose their stock trading plans when trading stocks in order to protect minority shareholders in the stock market.

However, it is necessary to be careful as there are also opinions opposing such government intervention. Passage D warns that government intervention to solve market inefficiencies can also fail. The government may not have enough information, and unintended effects may occur, causing government failure. Passage E also opposes government intervention, arguing that if the system is removed, the free system will naturally establish itself.
comment: This question addresses the 'information asymmetry' problem common in high school economics textbooks. The passages demonstrate various social problems arising from information asymmetry and question whether government intervention is necessary. The question assesses understanding of core concepts, their social manifestations, and critical thinking about government intervention.

Economics/Business.subject: Economics
Economics/Business.question: Based on Passages A and B, infer why local governments are competitively pushing for the introduction of local currency, and using Passages E and F, infer and argue why the introduction of local currency can cause the phenomenon in Passage D despite the theoretical basis in Passage C.
reference_answer: Passages [A] and [B] present the fundamental reasons why local governments are rushing to expand the issuance of local currency. Local currency can have a distributive effect of transferring sales from large marts to small business owners by restricting its use mainly to alley economies operated by small business owners. It can also be expected to increase sales and income within the region by restricting consumption that flows out to external regions. Finally, there is the advantage that a significant portion of the costs necessary for issuing local currency can be transferred to the central government. From the perspective of each region, this is almost the same as promoting the sales of their regional products and services through central government subsidies. For elected local government heads, local currency can only be attractive. The theoretical basis for introducing local currency can be found in [C]. First, local currency can prevent the outflow of consumption outside the region because it is only valid within a specific region. This plays an important role in revitalizing the local economy. Second, local currency has the effect of supporting small business owners, and by restricting its use to member stores with sales of less than 100 million won, it provides direct benefits to local small business owners rather than large distributors. However, despite this theoretical basis, the introduction of local currency can cause side effects such as moral hazard mentioned in [D]. Due to the central government's uniform subsidies, local governments that issue local currency first may secure more budget, which can result in local governments with better financial conditions being able to issue more local currency. In addition, many empirical research results showing that the issuance of local currency did not increase overall retail sales and did not have a significant impact on employment size leave many questions about the efficiency of introducing local currency. The inefficiency of introducing local currency can also be inferred through the relationship between substitute and complementary goods mentioned in [E]. Through [E], it can be inferred that for the relatively decreasing prices of traditional market products due to the circulation of local currency to lead to an increase in the demand for traditional market products, there must be substitutability between traditional market products and large mart products. The problem is that in most regions, the substitutability between small business owner or traditional market products and services, which are the target of local currency, and large mart products and services may not be large. This is because the products and services sold at traditional markets and large marts show clear differences in terms of diversity and quality. These differences could be one of the main factors weakening the link between local currency and small business owner sales. Also, the possibility of government failure mentioned in [F] should be considered. If the introduction of local currency is indiscriminately promoted with good intentions alone without accurate information about such substitutability, government intervention may distort the market or cause unintended side effects. This could ultimately undermine the original purpose of introducing local currency. In conclusion, the reason local governments are competitively promoting the introduction of local currency is based on the distinctly local selfish purpose of achieving local economic revitalization and protection of small business owners through central government subsidies. However, despite this theoretical basis, there is also the possibility of causing side effects such as moral hazard and government failure due to the absence of substitutability between local currency target products and services and large corporation products and services. Therefore, to operate the local currency policy effectively, continuous efforts should be made to find sophisticated ways to minimize these side effects and achieve the original purposes of revitalizing the local economy and protecting small business owners.
comment: · This question was designed to evaluate whether examinees can analyze why discrepancies can occur between policy introduction purposes and results through economic concept application and logical reasoning, using knowledge that can be acquired in high school <Economics> and information from media and policy reports, through the example of local governments' 'local currency' introduction policy. · Through Passages [A] and [B], examinees should grasp the concept that local currency is not a currency in the traditional economic sense but a 'voucher' only valid within the region, and should discern that political gains from regional closure and nationwide burden of costs are key reasons for local governments' competitive introduction of local currency policies. · From Passages [C] and [D], examinees should understand that the theoretical basis for introducing local currency emphasizes directing consumption within the region and supporting small business owners, and should be able to understand and explain that despite this theoretical basis, results different from expectations can actually occur. · Through Passages [E] and [F], examinees should be able to infer that one of the reasons why demand for local small business owners' products hasn't significantly increased is that large corporation products and services may not be perfect substitutes for products and services provided by local small business owners. Additionally, examinees should be able to grasp and logically explain that if the government promotes the introduction of local vouchers without accurately understanding these empirical facts, it could lead to government failure in the form of enormous administrative cost waste.

Passage [A] explains the concept of local currency and the basic intention of the policy. It was introduced as a type of voucher that can only be used at small retail stores operated by small business owners within the relevant local government, with the goal of protecting small business owners and revitalizing the local economy. It has the characteristic of using methods such as discounted sales by local governments or payment as welfare benefits to promote the circulation of local currency. Passage [B] summarizes two characteristics of local currency. The first is regional closure, where it can only be used at small businesses and traditional markets within the issuing local government. The second is the nationwide burden of costs; for example, if a 100,000 won local currency is sold for 90,000 won, when a small business owner claims 100,000 won from the local government, the local government bears the difference of 10,000 won, and the central government supports a portion of that, for example, about 40%. Passage [C] theoretically identifies the positive effects induced by the introduction of local currency. First, by being usable only within a specific region, it prevents the outflow of consumption and encourages local consumption. In particular, most local currencies cannot be used for online payments, which has the effect of promoting local consumption. Second, it has the effect of supporting small business owners by restricting membership to businesses with sales of less than 100 million won and applying lower payment fees than credit cards, providing benefits to small business owners. Passage [D] explains that despite these theoretical advantages and good intentions, the introduction of local currency tends to cause disadvantages rather than advantages in practice. First, due to the central government's uniform subsidies, local governments with better financial conditions can issue more local currencies, which can actually cause moral hazard for local governments. Second, many empirical research results show that local currency has not increased overall retail sales or had a significant impact on local employment. Passage [E] shows that there is an economic logic hidden in this discrepancy between theory and practice. By explaining the economic concepts of substitute and complementary goods, it aims to have examinees infer that if there is no flexible substitutability between traditional market products and large mart products, the effect of local currency on revitalizing small business owners may be reduced. Passage [F] implies that if the government promotes the introduction of local currency solely for the purpose of supporting small business owners without accurately grasping the substitutability between small business owner products and large marts or large corporation products, a typical example of government failure, far from achieving the goal the government initially intended to realize, could occur due to moral hazard and information incompleteness.

Economics/Business.subject: Ethics and Political Philosophy
Economics/Business.question: Apply the ethical perspectives presented in [D] and [E] to [A], [B], and [C] to comprehensively discuss the issues of globalization debates, and discuss whether the perspectives of [D] and [E] applied to the phenomenon of globalization are mutually exclusive or complementary.
reference_answer: [D] explains Bentham's utilitarian view of justice. [E] is Rawls's theory of distributive justice. [A] is an explanation of the meaning and phenomenon of globalization. [B] and [C] are claims about the benefits and costs brought about by the phenomenon of globalization. [A] describes that globalization is a process of deepening interdependence, and while the need for global village cooperation is increasing, competition among individuals, companies, and countries is becoming more intense. According to the claim in [B], as international division of labor progresses to efficiently utilize resources due to the influence of globalization, efficiency is maximized and the overall wealth of society increases. However, according to the claim in [C], the claim in [B] is a one-sided logic of groups enjoying the benefits of globalization, and in reality, the gap between rich and poor between countries and classes is widening as a result of globalization. From the perspective of utilitarianism in [D], examining the phenomenon of globalization, as an economic action, globalization can cause social benefits as well as costs, so if the benefits exceed the costs after carefully comparing them, globalization can be justified. However, this utilitarian view of justice can make the error of overlooking the rights of entities (individual countries, companies, individuals, etc.) under the pretext that overall benefits are increased through globalization. According to Rawls's view of distributive justice in [E], the situation in which the large gap in income and wealth caused by globalization can be judged as fair is when the market economy and free trade system of globalization that produces unequal distribution also brings benefits to the marginalized classes in society. From this perspective of distributive justice, the inherent production of inequality in the phenomenon of globalization in [C] cannot be seen as justifiable. While the utilitarian view of justice in [D] argues for justice based on the costs and benefits of society as a whole, Rawls's view of justice in [E] focuses on achieving a fair distribution of income and wealth from the perspective of entities, namely countries, companies, and individuals, rather than overall costs and benefits. The ideologies of [D] and [E] applied to the phenomenon of globalization are mutually complementary logics that can comprehensively encompass the debate on globalization from the perspective of the whole and the individual, costs and benefits.
comment: This question was designed so that answers could be written based only on the content of the passages excerpted from textbooks, regardless of prior knowledge outside the curriculum. Specifically, the purpose of this question is to discuss the light and shadow of globalization with an integrated perspective such as economic, social, and ethical viewpoints on the opposing claims about globalization presented in [A]-[C]. [A] explains the meaning and phenomenon of globalization. [B] argues that as a result of globalization, international division of labor is progressing to efficiently utilize resources, and it is creating economic benefits throughout the world economy. [C] argues that economic inequality is deepening due to globalization, and in fact, the economic gap between developed and developing countries, and between sectors with strong and weak competitiveness, is growing. [D] explains Bentham's utilitarian view of justice. [E] explains Rawls's theory of distributive justice.
checklist: Did the response understand and distinguish between the logic of globalization's benefits in terms of efficiency of resource utilization in [B] and the logic of globalization's costs in terms of deepening inequality between countries and classes in [C]?

Did the response understand and distinguish that Bentham's utilitarianism in [D] pursues an increase in overall benefits while Rawls's view of justice in [E] focuses on distributive justice from the perspective of individuals?
Did the response explain the passage [B], which argues for the benefits of globalization, in relation to the utilitarian perspective of [D]?
Did the response explain the passage [C], which argues for the costs of globalization, in relation to Rawls's view of justice in [E]?

Did the response understand that Bentham's utilitarianism in [D], which looks at benefits and costs from an overall perspective, and Rawls's view of justice in [E], which looks at fairness of distribution between entities, are complementary to each other?

Economics/Business.subject: Sociology
Economics/Business.question: Based on the content of Passage A, explain the data shown in Passages B and C, and write the implications for the situation in our country described in Passage E, using Passages A and D as grounds.
reference_answer:
Passage A defines 'social mobility' as the phenomenon of changing social class positions for individuals or groups.
In a society where fair opportunities are given to everyone and the possibility of social mobility is high, there is a greater potential for social development.
Passage B quantifies intergenerational class mobility through the indicator of intergenerational income elasticity, and the degree of inequality through the Gini coefficient.
According to the data, there is a positive correlation between countries' Gini coefficients and intergenerational income elasticity, which suggests that countries with higher inequality may experience more difficult intergenerational class mobility.

The statistical data in Passage C shows that higher-ranked universities have a higher proportion of students from socioeconomically privileged backgrounds, indicating that higher education opportunities are not equal in American society.
When synthesizing these facts, it becomes clear that university education opportunities, which play a crucial role in reducing income disparities, are concentrated among the upper classes, with limited access for low-income and middle-class families to top-tier universities.
Therefore, the graph in Passage B suggests that the United States may experience even higher intergenerational income elasticity or an increased Gini coefficient.

Passage D lists examples of meritocracy in the United States, where capable individuals become elites and leaders, while simultaneously arguing that the political leadership selected through meritocracy does not necessarily guarantee success.
Passage E describes how in our country, while there was hope for social mobility during the high-growth period, recently such social mobility has become increasingly difficult.

As claimed in Passage A, the openness that allows active social mobility is a critical factor in social development.
However, as argued in Passage D, a society where social mobility occurs based on ability and where capable individuals become elites and ruling classes does not necessarily guarantee an equal society.
This is because in the case of the United States, while the society has become more open compared to the past, this has not necessarily resolved inequality.

The above figure shows the relationship between income inequality and intergenerational income elasticity in OECD countries. The variable on the Y-axis is the Gini coefficient of each country. The Gini coefficient is an index that represents the degree of inequality in income distribution, with values between 0 and 1, and the closer to 0, the lower the degree of inequality in income distribution. Economics/Business.subject: Environmental Policy and International Relations
Economics/Business.question: Based on the claims in Passages A through C, analyze the problems presented in Passages D and E, and discuss how the methods suggested in Passages F and G can help solve these problems.
reference_answer:
Passage A argues that environmental problems, as a common task for humanity, must be solved from a global perspective, while Passage B claims that difficulties arise in finding solutions due to varying national interests.

According to Passage C, as globalization continues, inequality and wealth disparities occur between developed and developing countries, and solving these problems requires a responsible attitude from developed countries and cooperation among developing countries.

Environmental problems between developed and developing countries can arise, as shown in Passage D, through pollution export, where developed countries transfer environmental pollution sources to developing countries for their own safety, which creates serious social problems for developing countries.

Moreover, as illustrated in Passage E, environmental issues like greenhouse gas emissions lead to climate justice problems where developing countries suffer relatively greater damages. These issues can trigger conflicts between developed and developing countries regarding the causes of environmental problems and respective responsibilities.

Therefore, a responsible approach from developed countries is necessary, and developing countries must also make efforts to contribute to solving environmental problems from a global perspective.

Passages F and G present examples of solutions to environmental problems between developed and developing countries. Passage F introduces the Clean Development Mechanism, a environmental support system where both parties can benefit, inducing sustainable voluntary cooperation.

Passage G introduces the Paris Agreement, a new climate change treaty that not only emphasizes support from developed countries to developing countries—who bear the primary responsibility for environmental issues—but also argues for the need to implement flexible approaches that enable developing countries to participate voluntarily and actively in globally solving environmental problems.
comment: This question deals with environmental issues commonly included in high school textbooks for 'Politics and Law,' 'Integrated Social Studies,' and 'Life and Ethics' courses. Through the given passages, we can understand that environmental problems require global cooperation, but are interpreted differently based on each country's interests. In the era of globalization, international cooperation is necessary to solve problems between developed and developing countries. The passages explain the imbalances between developed and developing countries regarding environmental issues and present cases of mutually beneficial and voluntary solutions to address these global environmental challenges. This question assesses whether one can identify the interconnectedness of the passages' claims and explain them through logical procedures.

According to Passage A, environmental problems are a common task for humanity that should be solved through global cooperation, not through domestic or interstate confrontation.

Passage B presents that while environmental problems are causing global issues, resolution is difficult due to differing national interests.

Passage C addresses the inequality and wealth gap between developed and developing countries in the international community, highlighting the necessary requirements for solving such problems.

Passage D reveals the problem of pollution export, where the causes of pollution are transferred to developing countries for the benefit of developed countries, and the subsequent issues faced by developing countries.

Passage E examines the greenhouse gas emission issue, a representative environmental problem in the international community, from the ethical perspective of climate justice, emphasizing the need for a responsible approach from developed countries.

Passage F introduces the Clean Development Mechanism (CDM) adopted in the Kyoto Protocol as a method for resolving environmental problems between developed and developing countries.

Passage G presents the Paris Agreement as a method for addressing environmental issues between developed and developing countries.

Economics/Business.subject: Competition Law / Antitrust Law
Economics/Business.question: Using Passages B, C, and D, explain the government policy in Passage A, and using Passages E and F, evaluate the policy in Passage A.
reference_answer:
Passage A explains the 'voluntary disclosure exemption system (leniency system)' that provides reduced sanctions or fines for companies that first report cartel facts.
This system is designed to incentivize voluntary disclosure among cartel participants under uncertain conditions where no one knows who will report first, ensuring they do not end up in a disadvantageous position.
This is similar to the 'Prisoner's Dilemma' situation presented in Passage D, where reporting becomes a more advantageous choice than denial.

Passage B describes 'market failure', where markets are imperfect or resource allocation is inefficient, using cartel behavior in oligopolistic markets as an example.
Cartels involve a few companies with market power colluding to manipulate production or pricing, unfairly pursuing profits and disrupting free market competition.

Passage C explains the government's role in establishing economic activity rules and creating an environment for free economic competition, using the Fair Trade Commission's regulation of unfair practices as an example.
From this, we can infer that the leniency system in Passage A is also a regulatory measure by the Fair Trade Commission to suppress cartels.

Passage E critiques the leniency system's weakness, pointing out that it provides reduced sanctions based solely on who reports first, regardless of whether a company is a principal offender or an accomplice.
It particularly criticizes that major offenders or large companies have been unilaterally benefiting from the system since its introduction.

However, Passage F highlights the positive functions of the leniency system, explaining its crucial role in recognizing and proving cartel facts during the detection process and its positive contribution to cartel prevention.
comment: This question addresses 'market failure' commonly included in high school textbooks for 'Integrated Social Studies' and 'Economics'. Through the passages, one can understand the government's role in establishing market economic order and solving problems that cannot be resolved within the market. Specifically, the Fair Trade Commission, a central administrative agency under special law, can intervene in the market to prevent monopolies and regulate unfair trading practices. The Fair Trade Commission introduced the 'voluntary disclosure exemption system (leniency system)' to increase the probability of proving and regulating cartel facts, placing cartel participants in a 'Prisoner's Dilemma' situation to resolve collusion issues. The question assesses whether one can logically explain the characteristics, positive functions, and potential drawbacks of the leniency system described in multiple passages.

Economics/Business.subject: Economics
Economics/Business.question: Based on the concept explained in Passage A, analyze the problem presented in Passage B from the perspective of Passage C, and discuss a solution by contrasting the perspectives of Passage D and Passage E.
reference_answer:
Passage A explains the concept of cost-push inflation. According to this concept, stagflation, a phenomenon in which economic recession and price increases occur simultaneously due to rising production costs, may appear, and there is a high possibility that economic entities will suffer damage as a result.
Passage B shows that such cost-push inflation is currently occurring worldwide. Accordingly, it indicates that the risk of stagflation, as presented in Passage A, is also increasing.
On the other hand, Passage C suggests that the impact of a negative phenomenon can vary from person to person. Applying this analogy to the phenomenon described in Passage B, it can be inferred that the impact of the recent cost-push inflation is not the same for everyone and may differ for individual economic entities.
Based on this discussion, Passage D and Passage E contrast solutions to the problem of the negative impact of cost-push inflation varying among economic entities.
Passage D first presents that there are consumers who are suffering from the occurrence of cost-push inflation and energy companies that are enjoying a boom due to increased refining margins and other factors resulting from this phenomenon. Furthermore, it shows the example of Spain, where the government is actively intervening to solve this problem. It secures financial resources by imposing a so-called "windfall tax" on energy companies that are benefiting from cost-push inflation and uses those resources to reduce the burden on consumers who are suffering from cost-push inflation.
In contrast, Passage E argues that such a solution through government intervention may rather have a negative impact on economic entities.
comment: This question deals with the concept of cost-push inflation, which is included in the high school textbook subject 'Economics'. Through the presented passages, it can be understood that the impact of cost-push inflation may differ among economic entities. Furthermore, it asks whether the government should intervene in the market to redistribute wealth between economic entities that benefit from cost-push inflation and those that suffer from it. This item evaluates the ability to understand the interrelationship between the contents argued by the contrasting passages on this topic and explain it through a logical procedure.
checklist: Did the response infer through Passage C that the impact of cost-push inflation shown in the passages may differ by economic entity?
Did the response accurately grasp the concept of 'windfall tax' as one of the countermeasures against such differing impacts on economic entities?
Did the response accurately contrast the perspectives of Passage D and Passage E on the 'windfall tax'?
